content:
Convert srt to vtt for web based captions

What srt and vtt formats mean and where to use them

SRT (SubRip Text) is a plain text subtitle format with numeric indexes and timecodes using commas for milliseconds. It is widely used in desktop video players and offline editing tools. VTT (WebVTT) is the W3C standard for HTML5 captions, it uses a WEBVTT header and periods for millisecond separation. In this guide we walk through how to convert srt to vtt using multiple tools.

Command line conversion with FFMPEG on Windows Linux Mac

FFMPEG is a cross platform tool that handles subtitle conversion natively. To convert a file run:

ffmpeg -i input.srt output.vtt

This reads SRT timecodes and writes a compliant WebVTT file. You can also batch convert srt to vtt with a simple shell loop.

Batch conversion using ffmpeg script

  • Place all .srt files in a folder
  • Run for f in *.srt; do ffmpeg -i "$f" "${f%.srt}.vtt"; done

Manual conversion in Notepad or text editor

Open the .srt file in Notepad or any text editor, change the first line to WEBVTT, replace commas in timecodes with periods, then save the file with a .vtt extension. This method lets you convert srt to vtt manually without installing external tools.

Automated conversion with Python scripts

Use Python and the webvtt-py library for programmatic conversion. Example steps:

  • Install the library: pip install webvtt-py
  • Write a script:
    import webvtt webvtt.from_srt('input.srt').save('output.vtt')

This snippet shows how to convert srt to vtt programmatically in just a few lines of code.

Batch and online tools integration with HappyScribe API

HappyScribe offers an API and a Caption generator that accepts SRT files via Automatic transcription or Human-made subtitles endpoints, then returns VTT. You can integrate this into your content pipeline and convert large volumes without manual steps.

Incorporating subtitles in Premiere and Adobe workflows

Adobe Premiere Pro can import SRT files and export WebVTT. Combine Premiere editing with the HappyScribe Subtitle editor plugin to fine tune captions, then export VTT for HTML5 delivery.

Benefits of converting srt to vtt for streaming and accessibility

VTT supports styling cues, text formatting, and metadata for accessible web content. Browsers implement WebVTT natively in the HTML5 <track> element. Converting SRT to VTT ensures compliance with web standards and enhances user experience on streaming platforms.

faq.question: How do I convert an SRT file to VTT using ffmpeg?
faq.answer: Run ffmpeg -i input.srt output.vtt in your terminal. This reads the SRT timecodes and outputs a valid WebVTT file with the appropriate header.

faq.question: Can I manually convert SRT to VTT without software?
faq.answer: Yes, open the SRT in a text editor, change the first line to WEBVTT, replace commas in timecodes with periods, then save with a .vtt extension.

faq.question: Is there a Python library for srt to vtt conversion?
faq.answer: The webvtt-py library supports SRT to VTT conversion: install via pip, then use webvtt.from_srt('input.srt').save('output.vtt') in your script.

faq.question: How can I batch convert multiple SRT files to VTT?
faq.answer: Use a shell loop with ffmpeg: for f in *.srt; do ffmpeg -i "$f" "${f%.srt}.vtt"; done. This processes all files in one command.

faq.question: Does HappyScribe support srt to vtt conversion via API?
faq.answer: Yes, HappyScribe’s API accepts SRT uploads through Automatic transcription or Human-made subtitles endpoints and returns VTT files programmatically.

🎬 Subtitle Format Comparison: SRT vs VTT

Feature SRT VTT
File Extension .srt 📄 .vtt 📜
MIME Type text/plain; charset=utf-8 text/vtt
Syntax Differences • Index numbers
• Timestamps: hh:mm:ss,ms → hh:mm:ss,ms
• No header
 • “WEBVTT” header
• Timestamps: hh:mm:ss.mmm → hh:mm:ss.mmm
• Optional region & note blocks
Metadata & Styling • Minimal (no colors/positions)
• Hacks via HTML tags (unsupported)
 • CSS-like cues: align, position, size, line
• Classes & voice tags
Web & Browser Compatibility • Requires JS/conversion
• No native <track> support
 • Native HTML5 <track>
• Supported by Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge 👍
Subtitle Positioning • Fixed bottom
• No line/position control
 • line, position, align
• Multiple regions (e.g., speaker names)
Common Use Cases • DVDs, Blu-ray, offline players
• YouTube auto-generated edits 		• Web streaming (HLS, DASH)
• Interactive transcripts & captions
File Size Implications • Slightly smaller
• Plain timestamps only 		• Slightly larger
• Extra header & styling directives

✅ Pros & ❌ Cons

  • SRT Pros: Simple, tiny, universal.
  • SRT Cons: No styling, poor web integration.
  • VTT Pros: Rich styling, HTML5 support, positioning.
  • VTT Cons: Slightly larger, extra header required.

📊 Use This If…

Format Use This If…
SRT You need maximum compatibility in offline players or you must keep file sizes ultra-small.
VTT You’re publishing on the web with HTML5 <video> and want styling, positioning, or interactive transcripts.
